questions.text: A patient has adult respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is the action of IL-8 in the pathogenesis in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neutrophil activation

 

In the pathogenesis of Adult Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS), Interleukin-8 (IL-8) plays a crucial role as a potent chemokine that specifically attracts and activates neutrophils.

 

Neutrophil activation is a critical step in the inflammatory cascade that exacerbates endothelial injury and subsequent lung damage in ARDS. Neutrophils, once activated, release proteases, reactive oxygen species, and other inflammatory mediators that contribute to the damage of the alveolar-capillary membrane, further aggravating the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endothelial injury: While endothelial injury is an important early event in ARDS, it is not directly caused by IL-8. Instead, endothelial injury triggers the release of cytokines, including IL-8, which then leads to neutrophil recruitment and activation.

 

Option C. Fibrin deposition: Fibrin deposition is a downstream event in ARDS and is a result of the damage caused by neutrophil activation and endothelial injury. IL-8 indirectly contributes to this through its role in neutrophil activation, but it is not directly responsible for fibrin deposition.

 

Option D. Macrophage activation: While macrophages are involved in the inflammatory response in ARDS, IL-8 primarily targets neutrophils, not macrophages. IL-8's main action is to attract and activate neutrophils rather than macrophages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IL-8 is a key mediator in ARDS that promotes neutrophil activation, which plays a major role in the amplification of inflammation and lung injury in the disease process.

choices.text: Bleeding is from the adjacent invading vessels

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented with complaints of recurrent bleeding. On examination, following was seen on the CECT. All are false except: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tumor vessel lack contractility

 

Based on the provided CT image and the clinical context of recurrent bleeding, the most accurate statement is Tumor vessels lack contractility, which contributes to the propensity for bleeding in tumorous growths.

 

"Tumor vessel lack contractility" is a true statement about tumor vessels. They are often abnormally formed, with poor structural integrity and can lack the ability to contract, which normally helps control bleeding when vessels are injured.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Outgrown the blood supply: Suggests that the lesion has grown faster than the blood vessels can proliferate to support it. This can lead to areas of necrosis within tumours.

 

Option C. Bleeding is from the adjacent invading vessels: Implies that the normal vessels adjacent to the tumor are the source of bleeding. However, the bleeding associated with tumors is usually due to the tumor vessels themselves because they are prone to rupture, not the adjacent normal vessels.

 

Option D. Lacks capsule: May or may not be true depending on the type of tumor. Some benign tumors have a well-defined capsule, while malignant tumors often lack a capsule. However, this option does not directly relate to the issue of bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor vessels are known to lack contractility, which contributes to the risk of bleeding associated with tumors, as they cannot constrict effectively to stop blood flow when damaged.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presented with complaints of paranasal sinus pain and bloody nasal discharge for the past few days. He also has a previous history of hemoptysis and hematuria. Imaging revealed multiple, bilateral, nodular cavitary infiltrates. Which of the following antibodies would be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) c-ANCA

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's presentation suggests granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis. GPA triad typically involves:

 

  • ENT involvement: Sinus pain and bloody nasal discharge (sinusitis).
  • Pulmonary involvement: Hemoptysis and cavitating nodules on imaging.
  • Renal involvement: Hematuria and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

 

The characteristic antibody associated with GPA is c-ANCA (cytoplasmic anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies), which targets proteinase 3.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ANA (Antinuclear Antibodies): Typically associated with systemic lupus erythematosus and other autoimmune diseases.

 

Option C. Anti-histone antibodies: Associated with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

 

Option D. Anti-Jo 1 antibodies: Associated with polymyositis and dermatomyositis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is associated with c-ANCA (anti-proteinase 3 antibodies), presenting with ENT, pulmonary, and renal involvement.

questions.text: Identify the operative procedure shown in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Resection and anastomosis

 

The image shows a suture line between two ends of the bowel, indicating that the ends of the bowel are being joined. This is typically done after a surgical procedure where a segment of the bowel has been removed, necessitating the rejoining of the remaining bowel ends. This procedure is known as resection and anastomosis. The visual cues of the bowel ends being sutured together are indicative of this procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary closure of perforation: This would involve suturing a perforation directly without removing a segment of the bowel, which is not shown in the image.

 

Option C. Ileostomy: This procedure involves creating an opening (stoma) on the surface of the skin, which is not depicted in the provided image. The image shows internal suturing, not an external stoma.

 

Option D. Resection alone: This would mean removing a section of the bowel without rejoining the ends, which is not shown in the image. The image clearly depicts the bowel ends being sutured together, indicating an anastomosis following resection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In surgical procedures involving the bowel, when two bowel ends are being sutured together, the procedure is referred to as resection and anastomosis.

questions.text: Identify the sinus marked in the given image: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Maxillary sinus

 

Marked structure is Maxillary sinus on a non-contrast CT.

 

The Maxillary sinus is one of the largest of the paranasal sinuses and is located in the maxillary bone under the eyes, bilaterally to the nasal cavity. On imaging, such as a non-contrast CT scan, the maxillary sinus is typically visible as a large, air-filled space below the orbits (eye sockets) and lateral to the nasal cavity.

 

Following images show paranasal sinuses and related structures:

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ethmoid Sinus: Located between the nose and the eyes, within the ethmoid bone. It is a collection of small air cells.
  • Frontal Sinus: Located above the eyes, in the frontal bone. These are typically well above the maxillary sinuses.
  • Sphenoid Sinus: Located deeper and more centrally behind the nasal cavity, in the sphenoid bone.
  • Maxillary Sinus: Located beneath the orbits, on either side of the nose.

questions.text: A Cattle farmer with a scab lesion in the arm. Microscopic examination shows brick/box shaped gram-positive organism with squared ends and spores in the centre. Most likely organism which is responsible for his condition is? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacillus anthracis

 

Given clinical scenario is suggestive of cutaneous anthrax caused by Bacillus anthracis. Bacillus anthracis is a brick/box car shaped gram-positive organism with squared ends and spores in the centre. It causes zoonotic infections in humans. It is non-motile and capsulated with a characteristic polypeptide capsule.

 

It can cause -

 

  • Cutaneous anthrax
  • Pulmonary anthrax
  • Intestinal anthrax

 

 

Box car appearance/bamboo stick appearance of bacillus anthracis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Listeria monocytogens: Incorrect. Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive rod that can cause listeriosis, but it does not have the brick/boxcar shape and is not typically associated with cutaneous lesions.

 

Option C. Bacillus cereus: Incorrect. Bacillus cereus can cause food poisoning and is a gram-positive rod, but it does not typically present with the brick/boxcar shape or cutaneous lesions.

 

Option D. Streptococcus: Incorrect. Streptococcus species are gram-positive cocci and do not exhibit the described morphology or cause anthrax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacillus anthracis, with its brick/boxcar shape and central spores, is the causative agent of cutaneous anthrax, a zoonotic infection often seen in individuals handling livestock or animal products.

questions.text: Which of the following are vitamin K dependent factors requiring gamma carboxylation? (NEETPG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 7, 9, 10

 

Vitamin K is essential for the post-translational modification of certain proteins required for blood coagulation. This modification is gamma carboxylation, which allows these proteins to bind calcium ions and participate effectively in the coagulation cascade.

 

Vitamin K Dependent Factors:

 

  • Procoagulants: Factors II (prothrombin), VII, IX, and X.
  • Anticoagulants: Protein C and Protein S.

 

These factors are synthesized in the liver and require gamma carboxylation of specific glutamic acid residues for their activity. Without this modification, they cannot bind calcium effectively, which is necessary for their role in coagulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin K dependent factors are procoagulants (factors 2,7,9,10) and anticoagulants (protein C and S). They require gamma carboxylation for their activity.

questions.text: A woman presenting with symptoms of urinary tract infection was prescribed a drug that causes tendon rupture and arthropathy. What is the mechanism of action of the drug? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DNA gyrase inhibition

 

The description of a drug causing tendon rupture and arthropathy, especially in the context of treating a urinary tract infection, points towards a fluoroquinolone antibiotic. Fluoroquinolones, such as ciprofloxacin, work by inhibiting bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, which are essential for bacterial DNA replication and transcription.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ribosomal Inhibition: Antibiotics that inhibit ribosomes, such as macrolides, tetracyclines, and aminoglycosides, affect protein synthesis. These drugs are not typically associated with tendon rupture or arthropathy.

 

Option C. Cell Wall Synthesis Inhibition: Drugs that inhibit cell wall synthesis, like beta-lactams (penicillins, cephalosporins) and vancomycin, are not known to cause tendon rupture or arthropathy as a common side effect.

 

Option D. Inhibition of Folic Acid Synthesis: Antibiotics that inhibit folic acid synthesis, such as sulfonamides and trimethoprim, do not typically cause tendon rupture or arthropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoroquinolones, which inhibit DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, are associated with serious side effects such as tendon rupture and arthropathy.

choices.text: Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected

questions.text: A female patient presents to the clinic with a painful lump in her breast that has been increasing in size over the past few days. After examination, the doctor diagnoses her with a breast abscess and prescribes antibiotics to help clear the infection. The doctor attempts to aspirate the abscess using a needle and syringe, but no fluid is obtained. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A second attempt at aspiration

 

Explanation:

 

If the first attempt at aspiration fails to obtain fluid, the next logical step is to attempt aspiration again, potentially with ultrasound guidance. Ultrasound guidance can enhance the accuracy of the procedure by allowing direct visualization of the abscess, ensuring that the needle is correctly positioned to access the abscess cavity. This method is less invasive than incision and drainage (I&D), making it a preferred option if it can effectively manage the abscess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incision and Drainage: Incision and drainage is generally considered if aspiration fails repeatedly or if the abscess is too large. While effective, it is not typically the immediate next step after a single failed aspiration attempt. It is more invasive than aspiration and usually reserved for cases where less invasive methods are unsuccessful.

 

Option B. Continue antibiotics only: Antibiotics are crucial in managing breast abscesses by treating the underlying infection. However, they alone might not suffice for large or dense abscesses. The pus trapped within the abscess often needs to be physically removed to expedite healing and provide symptom relief. Continuing antibiotics without addressing the abscess can lead to prolonged infection and discomfort.

 

Option D. Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected: This option is not recommended. The failure to collect aspirate does not imply the absence of infection. The antibiotics were prescribed based on the clinical diagnosis of a breast abscess, and stopping them prematurely could allow the infection to worsen. Continuation of antibiotics is important until the course is complete or unless indicated otherwise by a physician.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If the initial aspiration attempt for a breast abscess fails, the next step should be to attempt aspiration again, preferably under ultrasound guidance, before considering more invasive procedures like incision and drainage. This approach ensures accurate access to the abscess and minimizes invasiveness.

questions.text: Which cell is involved in type 4/delayed type hypersensitivity? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytotoxic T cell

 

Type IV hypersensitivity, also known as delayed-type hypersensitivity, involves T cells, particularly cytotoxic T cells (CD8+ T cells) and helper T cells (TH1 cells). When these T cells recognize antigen presented by antigen-presenting cells (like macrophages and dendritic cells), they secrete cytokines that activate macrophages and cytotoxic T cells. This leads to an inflammatory response that can cause tissue damage. The process typically takes 24-72 hours to develop, hence the term "delayed."

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macrophage: Macrophages play a crucial role in presenting antigens and secreting cytokines, but they are not the primary cells involved in mediating the type IV hypersensitivity response.

 

Option C. Dendritic cell: Dendritic cells are important antigen-presenting cells that activate T cells, but they are not the main effector cells in type IV hypersensitivity.

 

Option D. Neutrophil: Neutrophils are involved in type III hypersensitivity reactions, where they mediate tissue damage through the release of enzymes and reactive oxygen species in response to immune complex deposition.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following option is a common size of a Foley catheter used in female patients and patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 14 Fr

 

14 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 14 Fr are commonly used in adult female patients. They are also used in patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 6 Fr: 6 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 6 Fr are commonly used in pediatric patients or in adults with narrow urethras. They are also used in urodynamic studies to measure bladder pressures.

 

Option C. 16 Fr: 16 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 16 Fr are commonly used in adult male patients. They are also used in patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures.

 

Option D. 22 Fr: 22 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 22 Fr are commonly used in patients for suprapubic cystostomy. They are also used in patients who have undergone prostate surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FOLEY’S CATHETER

 

The size in French (12F, 14F, 16F etc.) represents the outer diameter. 1 F = 1/3rd mm.

questions.text: A young patient undergoing treatment for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) presents with symptoms of weight gain, cold intolerance, and lethargy. Laboratory investigations reveal high levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and low levels of T3 (triiodothyronine) and T4 (thyroxine). Which of the following drugs is likely responsible for these symptoms? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ethionamide.

 

Ethionamide, a second-line antitubercular agent used in the treatment of MDR-TB, is known to cause hypothyroidism as a side effect. This condition is characterized by an underactive thyroid gland, leading to symptoms such as weight gain, cold intolerance, and lethargy. The laboratory findings of elevated TSH and low levels of T3 and T4 further support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cycloserine: Cycloserine is used in the treatment of MDR-TB, but its side effects are more commonly neurological, including mood changes and seizures. It is not typically associated with thyroid dysfunction.

 

Option C. Streptomycin: Streptomycin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic, is used in TB treatment and is known for its potential ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity, rather than effects on thyroid function.

 

Option D. Pyrazinamide: Pyrazinamide is a first-line anti-TB medication. Its side effects include hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia but not typically hypothyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethionamide, a second-line drug used in the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB), can cause hypothyroidism, characterized by symptoms such as weight gain, cold intolerance, lethargy, elevated TSH, and low T3 and T4 levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary identification made by a CBNAAT or GeneXpert? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MTB + Rifampicin resistance

 

Explanation:

 

The Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT), also known as GeneXpert, is a molecular diagnostic test used for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and its resistance to the anti-tubercular drug rifampicin.

 

The key points are:

 

  1. CBNAAT or GeneXpert is a molecular method based on real-time PCR that can detect the presence of MTB. (Detection  limit  à about 131 bacilli/mL of specimen)
  2. In addition to detecting MTB, it can also detect resistance to the drug rifampicin by identifying mutations in the rpoB gene, which is associated with rifampicin resistance
  3. CBNAAT/GeneXpert primarily identifies the presence of MTB and rifampicin resistance.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: While CBNAAT can detect the presence of MTB, it also provides information on rifampicin resistance, making this option incomplete.

 

Option C. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Isoniazid resistance: CBNAAT does not directly detect resistance to isoniazid, another first-line anti-tubercular drug.

 

Option D. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Ethambutol resistance: CBNAAT does not detect resistance to ethambutol, another first-line anti-tubercular drug.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT or GeneXpert) is a molecular diagnostic tool that primarily identifies the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and its resistance to the anti-tubercular drug rifampicin by detecting mutations in the rpoB gene.

 

Additional Information –

 

Laboratory Diagnosis

 

  1. Direct microscopy by acid-fast staining
  2. Kinyoun’s Cold acid-fast Staining
  3. Fluorescence Staining
  4. Culture Methods
    1. Conventional Media
    2. Automated Liquid Culture  à BACTEC MGIT
  5. Molecular Methods

  6. Polymerase Chain reaction (PCR)

  7. Automated real Time PCR  à  CBNAAT, TrueNat

 

RNTCP diagnostic algorithm -

choices.text: Placenta weight at term is 470 g
Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

questions.text: The following are correct regarding normal placenta, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

 

Explanation:


The statement in option C is incorrect regarding the normal placenta.

 

Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present: In a normal placenta, the umbilical cord typically contains three vessels (two arteries and one vein), not two. The presence of extraplacental membranes (membranes extending beyond the placental margins) is not a feature of a normal placenta; it is rather an abnormal finding if present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta weight at term is 470 g: This is correct. The average weight of a term placenta is around 500 grams, but it can range from approximately 450 to 700 grams. The option provides a reasonable estimate.

 

Option B. Round-oval with 22 cm diameter: This is partially correct. The normal placenta is indeed round to oval, but the average diameter is about 15-20 cm, not 22 cm. The provided diameter exceeds the typical range.

 

Option D. Central thickness > 2.5 cm: This is correct. The normal thickness of the placenta at term is greater than 2.5 cm, commonly around 2.5 to 4 cm. A thickness greater than 2.5 cm falls within the normal range.

 

Educational Objective:


The normal placenta at term typically weighs around 500 grams, has a diameter of 15-20 cm, is 2.5 cm thick, and has a 3-vessel umbilical cord with a central insertion.

 

Ref: Page 245 Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A multiparous woman from a low socio-economic status whose husband is a truck driver is to be screened for cervical cancer. What is the best way? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pap smear

 

Explanation:

 

Cervical cancer screening is crucial for early detection and prevention. The Pap smear (Papanicolaou test) is the standard screening test for cervical cancer, particularly in resource-limited settings. It involves collecting cells from the cervix to detect precancerous or cancerous changes.

 

Why Pap Smear?

 

  • Accessibility: It is widely available and can be performed in low-resource settings.
  • Cost-effective: It is a cost-effective method for cervical cancer screening.
  • Proven efficacy: It has been proven to significantly reduce the incidence and mortality of cervical cancer through early detection and treatment of precancerous lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CA125: This is a biomarker used in the screening and monitoring of ovarian cancer, not cervical cancer.

 

Option B. Laparoscopy: This is a surgical procedure used for diagnosis and treatment but not for routine screening.

 

Option C. TVS (Transvaginal Sonography): Primarily used for evaluating the uterus and ovaries, not suitable for cervical cancer screening.

 

Educational objective:

 

The Pap smear is the best and most widely recommended screening test for cervical cancer, especially in low socio-economic and resource-limited settings.

questions.text: A photographer who recently returned from Africa presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations. He died despite treatment, and an autopsy revealed intranuclear Torres bodies in the liver. Which of the following vaccines could have prevented it? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 17D

 

The above clinical vignette is suggestive of yellow fever and the use of 17D vaccine could have prevented this.

 

17D vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine administered through the subcutaneous route. It is contraindicated in infants less than 9 months of age, in pregnancy, and in individuals with egg allergy.

 

Yellow fever is caused by flavivirus and is endemic to certain parts of Africa and America. It occurs in two patterns: the urban cycle and the sylvatic cycle. Aedes aegypti is the vector in the urban cycle, while Aedes africanus is responsible for transmission in the sylvatic cycle.

 

Patients present with acute onset fever, headache, and vomiting. Jaundice and hemorrhagic manifestations can also be present. Ultimately, hepatic or renal failure can result in death.

 

Torres bodies are intranuclear eosinophilic inclusion bodies in hepatocytes. These are rarely seen in yellow fever. To prevent the establishment of the disease in India, strict vaccination and quarantine protocols for travelers from endemic areas are enforced.

 

Other options:

 

Option B: Nakayama vaccine is used for immunization against Japanese encephalitis. Culex tritaeniorhynchus is the principal vector. There is a sudden onset of fever and vomiting, which later progresses to encephalitis. In India, it was first reported in Vellore and continues to be active in the country.

 

Option C. Weigl's vaccine is the earliest used vaccine against epidemic typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. The main foci of the disease are Europe, Africa, South America, and Asia. Kashmir is the endemic spot in India. Pediculus humans corporis (human body louse) is the vector. Symptoms include fever and chills. A characteristic rash on the trunk and limbs, sparing the face, palms, and soles, may also be seen.

 

Option D. Jeryl-Lynn strain of the mumps virus is used against the disease as a live-attenuated vaccine. It is contraindicated in pregnancy and individuals allergic to eggs. Mumps present as parotid swelling associated with fever and tenderness.

 

Educational Objective

 

The 17D vaccine could have prevented the yellow fever that led to the photographer's severe symptoms and death. This highlights the importance of appropriate vaccination before traveling to areas where yellow fever is endemic.

choices.text: Gall bladder thickness >3 mm on USG
Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan

questions.text: 50-year-old obese female presents to the emergency department with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and nausea. The physician suspects acute cholecystitis and orders imaging studies to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following statements is not true about acute cholecystitis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan.

 

This statement is not true. In a Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid (HIDA) scan, the gallbladder is not preferentially visualized in acute cholecystitis. Instead, one of the hallmark findings in acute cholecystitis on a HIDA scan is non-visualization of the gallbladder due to inflammation and obstruction of the cystic duct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gall bladder thickness >3 mm on USG: This statement is true and is a common finding in acute cholecystitis. On ultrasound (USG), a thickened gallbladder wall, typically greater than 3 mm, is indicative of inflammation and is a characteristic feature of acute cholecystitis.

 

Option B. Murphy's sign positive: This statement is true. Murphy's sign is a clinical maneuver used to assess for acute cholecystitis. It involves palpation of the right upper quadrant during inspiration, and if the patient experiences pain or stops breathing due to pain during this maneuver, it is considered a positive Murphy's sign, suggesting inflammation of the gallbladder.

 

Option C. Leukocytosis: This statement is true. Acute cholecystitis is associated with an inflammatory response, leading to an elevation in white blood cell count, which is known as leukocytosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute cholecystitis is a common condition characterized by inflammation of the gallbladder, typically due to the presence of gallstones obstructing the cystic duct. Clinical features of acute cholecystitis include right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis. A positive Murphy's sign is right upper quadrant tenderness on palpation. On ultrasound imaging, gall bladder thickness >3 mm is a common finding in acute cholecystitis. The HIDA scan is a diagnostic tool for acute cholecystitis, showing non-visualization of the gall bladder 3 hours after radioisotope administration. Preferential visualization of the gall bladder on a HIDA scan is not a feature of acute cholecystitis. It is important to diagnose and treat acute cholecystitis promptly to prevent complications such as gallbladder perforation or gangrene.

questions.text: Laryngismus stridulus is due to which of the following vitamin deficiencies? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin D

 

Laryngismus stridulus, also known as laryngospasm, is a condition characterized by a sudden and involuntary contraction of the vocal cords, which can lead to difficulty in breathing and a high-pitched sound known as stridor. This condition is often associated with hypocalcemia, which can be a consequence of Vitamin D deficiency.

 

Vitamin D plays a crucial role in calcium homeostasis by promoting calcium absorption in the gut. A deficiency in Vitamin D leads to decreased calcium levels in the blood, which can trigger neuromuscular excitability and result in laryngospasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency typically leads to neurological problems due to oxidative stress but is not associated with laryngospasm or hypocalcemia.

 

Option C. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects vision (night blindness) and the immune system. It does not cause laryngospasm.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy, characterized by bleeding gums, bruising, and poor wound healing, but not laryngospasm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngismus stridulus (laryngospasm) can be caused by hypocalcemia, which is often a result of Vitamin D deficiency.

questions.text: In a patient with lipoprotein lipase deficiency, which of the following is increased following a fatty meal? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chylomicron

 

Chylomicron levels are increased following a fatty meal in individuals with lipoprotein lipase deficiency. Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is responsible for breaking down triglycerides in chylomicrons. In its absence, chylomicrons accumulate in the bloodstream, leading to elevated chylomicron levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. LDL: LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein) levels may be elevated as well in individuals with lipoprotein lipase deficiency, but this increase is primarily associated with genetic factors and not directly related to a fatty meal.

 

Option C. HDL: HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein) levels are typically not significantly affected by lipoprotein lipase deficiency.

 

Option D. Apo A: Apolipoprotein A (Apo A) is a component of HDL and is not directly increased following a fatty meal in individuals with lipoprotein lipase deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frederickson’s classification of hyperlipoproteinemia

choices.text: Anthracotic pigment

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with cough, fatigability, and weight loss. He was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) on bronchoscopy. The resected specimen had a hilar lymph node that was 1cm in size and showed a black pigment. What is the black pigment likely to be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anthracotic pigment

 

The black pigment in the resected bronchoscopic specimen's hilar lymph node is most likely an anthracotic pigment.

 

The black colour is caused by carbon particle deposition. Carbon particles inhaled are engulfed by lung macrophages and transported to the hilar lymph nodes. This builds up and causes anthracosis, or blackening of the lung tissues.

 

 

It is commonly seen in people who work in environments with high levels of carbon particle pollution, such as coal mines. It is also the most common exogenous pigment found in humans as a result of urban air pollution. The aggregates of the carbon dust may induce fibroblastic reaction or emphysema that may lead to a condition called coal worker's pneumoconiosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanin: Melanin is a natural pigment found in the skin, hair, and eyes. It is not typically found in the lungs or lymph nodes.

 

Option C. Lipochrome: Lipochrome (also known as lipofuscin) is a yellow-brown pigment that accumulates with age in various tissues, but it does not present as black and is not typically found in the lungs or lymph nodes.

 

Option D. Hemosiderin: Hemosiderin is an iron-storage complex and presents as a golden-brown pigment. It is associated with hemorrhage and iron metabolism but does not appear as black.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anthracotic pigment, resulting from the deposition of carbon particles, is the most likely cause of the black pigment observed in the hilar lymph node of a patient with squamous cell carcinoma. This is common in individuals exposed to high levels of environmental pollution or occupational hazards involving carbon particles.

questions.text: The most radiosensitive phase of the cell cycle is: (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) G2 phase

 

Each phase of the cell cycle exhibits different levels of sensitivity to radiation damage:

 

This is the second gap phase after DNA synthesis where the cell prepares for mitosis. Cells in the G2 phase are more sensitive to radiation than those in the G1 and S phases, as the cell checks for DNA damage and repairs it before proceeding to mitosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. M Phase (Mitosis): This is the phase where the cell divides into two daughter cells.. The cell's machinery is entirely focused on the mitotic process, making it less able to repair DNA damage effectively.

 

Option C. S Phase: During this phase, DNA replication occurs. Cells are more resistant to radiation in the S phase because the DNA is actively being synthesized, and the repair processes are robust.

 

Option D. G1 Phase: This is the first gap phase, where cells increase in size and prepare the necessary components for DNA synthesis. Cells in the G1 phase are relatively resistant to radiation compared to other phases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most radiosensitive phase of the cell cycle is the G2-> M  (G2>M) phase. During this phase cells are particularly vulnerable to radiation because any damage caused during this phase can lead to immediate catastrophic errors in cell division, leading to cell death.

questions.text: A farmer had a thorn prick 3 weeks ago and presents with difficulty in opening jaw and muscle cramps. He is also having breathlessness. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tetanus

 

The patient presents with classic symptoms of tetanus, which include difficulty in opening the jaw (trismus), muscle cramps, and breathlessness. Tetanus is caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani, which is often introduced through a wound such as a thorn prick. The symptoms of tetanus can develop days to weeks after the initial injury, as is the case here with the 3-week history.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strychnine poisoning: Strychnine poisoning can cause severe muscle spasms and cramps, but it typically presents acutely and is associated with a history of ingestion of the poison rather than an injury. Additionally, strychnine poisoning does not usually present with trismus (lockjaw).

 

Option C. Meningitis: Meningitis can cause symptoms like headache, fever, and neck stiffness, but it does not typically cause muscle cramps and difficulty in opening the jaw in the manner described.

 

Option D. Rabies: Rabies can cause neurological symptoms including hydrophobia and agitation, but it does not usually present with muscle cramps and trismus as seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of tetanus should be considered in a patient with a history of a wound or injury followed by symptoms such as trismus, muscle cramps, and breathlessness, particularly if the onset of symptoms is delayed.

choices.text: X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets
Vitamin D dependent rickets type I
Vitamin D dependent rickets type II

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presented with developmental delay, recurrent chest infections and worsening bony pain. His serum PTH was normal. Calcium was normal and phosphate was low. There is no response to Vitamin D. The probable diagnosis is:(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets

 

  • X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets is a genetic disorder characterized by low phosphate levels in the blood due to impaired phosphate reabsorption by the kidneys. This condition can lead to bone deformities, bony pain, and growth delays. Normal PTH levels are consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Nutritional rickets:

  • Nutritional rickets is typically caused by a deficiency of Vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. In this case, the boy has normal serum PTH, which suggests that his body is not compensating for a Vitamin D deficiency. Additionally, his phosphate levels are low despite Vitamin D supplementation, which is not characteristic of nutritional rickets.

 

Option C: Vitamin D dependent rickets type I:

  • This condition is caused by a genetic mutation that impairs the conversion of Vitamin D to its active form. It usually presents with low calcium levels and elevated PTH, which is not in line with the boy's normal PTH levels.

 

Option D: Vitamin D dependent rickets type II:

  • Vitamin D dependent rickets type II is another genetic disorder that affects the body's response to Vitamin D. It can lead to low calcium levels and elevated PTH, which do not match the boy's normal PTH levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets is a genetic disorder that results in low phosphate levels and can present with bony pain, developmental delay, and recurrent infections. It is distinct from other forms of rickets due to its genetic basis and the characteristic low phosphate levels in the absence of Vitamin D response.

 

Ref- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK562285/

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child came to the casualty with difficulty in walking and pain in the perianal region. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, yellow needle-shaped crystals are seen under the microscope. What is the test done? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barberio’s Test

 

As the crystals are seen under the microscope, this indicates that it is a microchemical test.

 

Barberio’s test

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Florence test

 

  • Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O
  • Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)
  • Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals)

 

 

Option C. Hemin (Teichmann’s) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid
  • Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • Negative in old stains or washed or treated with chemicals

 

 

Option D. Acid phosphatase test: It’s a non-cellular Semen Markers i.e. markers are specific and unique to seminal plasma but independent of spermatozoa.

 

Finding a significantly elevated acid phosphatase level is consistent with the presence of semen. Undiluted semen has an acid phosphatase level of 340–360 Bodansky units/ml. A value of > 100 Bodansky units with/without motile sperms indicate that ejaculation occurred within 12 h of examination. Level decreases with time after intercourse, and there is little chance of identifying it after 48 h.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)

 

Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)

 

Non-cellular Semen Markers: Acid phosphatase test (quantitative), Prostate specific antigen or PSA (p30)

questions.text: Match the Dermatological disorders in Column A with their respective investigations in Column B: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d

 

Explanation:

 

Correct matches:

 

 

1. Tinea: Tinea infections, also known as dermatophytosis, are fungal infections of the skin, hair, or nails. The diagnosis is commonly made by performing a potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount of skin scrapings, which reveals fungal hyphae under a microscope.

 

2. Lepromatous leprosy: This form of leprosy is diagnosed using a slit skin smear, where a sample from the skin lesion is stained and examined for the presence of acid-fast bacilli (Mycobacterium leprae).

 

 

3. Lupus vulgaris: Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis. The diagnosis often involves a biopsy of the lesion, which shows granulomatous inflammation with caseation necrosis and the presence of acid-fast bacilli.

 

4. Allergic dermatitis: Allergic contact dermatitis is diagnosed using a patch test, where suspected allergens are applied to the skin under occlusive patches to observe for a delayed hypersensitivity reaction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tinea is diagnosed with a KOH mount, lepromatous leprosy with a slit skin smear, lupus vulgaris with a biopsy, and allergic dermatitis with a patch test.

questions.text: As per Nutrition Guidelines of India, a 55 kg woman needs how many grams of proteins? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 45 grams

 

Explanation:

 

According to the nutrition guidelines of India, the protein requirement for adults is based on body weight.

 

The recommended daily protein intake is 0.83 grams per kilogram of body weight. For an adult reference Indian woman weighing 55 kg, this translates to approximately 45 grams of protein per day (0.83 grams/kg/day x 55 kg = 45.65 grams/day, rounded to 45 grams).

 

Additional Information –

 

The recommended daily energy intake: [NEW GUIDELINES 2021-22]

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A 55 kg woman requires approximately 45 grams of protein per day according to the nutrition guidelines of India.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented to OPD with complaint of greenish-frothy vaginal discharge for 1 month. Examination revealed finding as shown in image. On saline microscopy, motile organisms are noticed. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichomoniasis

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario and image showing strawberry cervix, is suggestive of Trichomoniasis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacterial Vaginosis

 

  • Discharge: White, thin, homogenous with a foul odor.
  • Diagnosis: Amsel Criteria - clue cells on wet mount, whiff test positive, pH > 4.5, homogenous discharge.
  • Symptoms: Usually no erythema or significant irritation.

 

Option C. Chlamydial Cervicitis

 

  • Typically associated with mucopurulent cervical discharge and may not present with frothy discharge or a strawberry cervix.
  • Diagnosis: Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT) are used to detect Chlamydia trachomatis.

 

Option D. Candidiasis

 

  • Discharge: Thick, curdy white with no odor.
  • Diagnosis: KOH prep revealing pseudohyphae or spores, wet mount.
  • Symptoms: Pruritis and dysuria with notable erythema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichomoniasis is characterized by greenish-frothy vaginal discharge, a strawberry cervix, and motile organisms on saline microscopy.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Gynaecology 6th edition page 166

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient had a tooth extraction three days back. He now presents with a mass in the submandibular region which is otherwise asymptomatic. There is no ulcer on the oral mucosa. On drainage of the discharge, it was foul-smelling with a lot of yellow granules. They showed gram-positive filamentous rods on grams staining. What is the most likely implicated pathogen? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Actinomycetes israelli

 

This clinical history is suggestive of cervicofacial actinomycosis which is caused by Actinomyces israeli.

 

Actinomyces are non-sporeforming, filamentous, and facultative anaerobes. They are normal constituents of the oral flora within gingival crevices and tonsillar crypts and are particularly prevalent in periodontal pockets, dental plaques, and on carious teeth.

 

Actinomyces bacteria cannot penetrate healthy tissue, and mucosal breakdown is a prerequisite for infection. Poor dental hygiene, caries, oral trauma, dental extraction, and an immunocompromised status are considered to be important antecedents.

 

Cervicofacial actinomycosis or lumpy jaw is the most frequent clinical form of actinomycosis, and “lumpy jaw syndrome”, which is associated with odontogenic infection, is the most common clinical manifestation.

 

It presents as a painless or occasionally painful soft-tissue swelling involving the submandibular or perimandibular region; over time, multiple sinuses drain pus containing sulfur granules; tendency to remit and recur. There is reddish or bluish discoloration of the skin overlying the lesion, chewing difficulties (i.e., with involvement of mastication muscles) are also seen.

 

Other types -

 

  • Thoracic actinomycosis- 
    • History of aspiration (Risk factors include seizure disorder, alcoholism, and poor dental hygiene.)
    • Dry or productive cough, occasionally blood-streaked sputum, shortness of breath, chest pain pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum.
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- 
    • History of abdominal surgery, perforated viscus, mesenteric vascular insufficiency, or ingestion of foreign bodies (e.g., fish or chicken bones)
  • Pelvic actinomycosis- 
    • History of IUCD
    • Lower abdominal discomfort, abnormal vaginal bleeding or discharge

 

A Gram-stained smear of the specimen may demonstrate the presence of beaded, branched, gram-positive filamentous rods, with a sun ray appearance suggesting the diagnosis of actinomycosis.

 

 

Culture - Grows slowly under anaerobic conditions, on blood or serum glucose agar at 37°C. After about a week, it appears as small, creamy-white, adherent colonies on blood agar. The colonies resemble breadcrumbs or the surface of ‘molar’ teeth. On solid media, A. israeli produces spidery colonies.

 

Treatment - Sensitive to penicillin, but prolonged courses up to 6 weeks are necessary for chronic infections. Oral penicillin’s such as amoxicillin are now popular. Recalcitrant lesions respond well to tetracycline because of its good bone penetration. Surgical intervention may be necessary in chronic jaw lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromoblastomycosis: This is a chronic fungal infection characterized by verrucous skin lesions, typically affecting the lower extremities. It does not present with the described symptoms and findings.

 

Option B. Mucormycosis: This is a severe fungal infection caused by fungi in the order Mucorales. It usually affects immunocompromised individuals and presents with rhino-orbital-cerebral or pulmonary infections, not typically associated with submandibular masses and sulfur granules.

 

Option D. Histoplasmosis: This is a fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, primarily affecting the lungs and sometimes disseminating in immunocompromised individuals. It does not typically present with the described symptoms and findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervicofacial actinomycosis, commonly caused by Actinomyces israelii, presents with submandibular masses, often after dental procedures, with foul-smelling discharge containing yellow sulfur granules. Gram staining reveals gram-positive filamentous rods, confirming the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old presented with swelling in the wrist joint. Histopathological examination of the swelling revealed spindle cells with palisading of the nuclei and Verocay bodies. Which of the following is the most likely condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schwannoma

 

The histopathological examination is suggestive of schwannoma.

 

Schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that surround but do not invade the associated nerve. They are frequently associated with NF2 gene inactivating mutations on chromosome 22g12.

 

The tumor is composed of fibrocellular bundles that form a whorled pattern under the microscope. There are dense and compact cellular areas (Antoni A pattern) that alternate with loose acellular areas (Antoni B pattern). Antoni A pattern areas have palisaded nuclei known as Verocay bodies. Nerve fibres are typically found stretched across the capsule but not within the tumor. Hemosiderin and lipid-laden macrophages are found in degeneration areas.

 

Schwann cells characteristically express S-100 protein.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neurofibroma: Neurofibromas are also benign nerve sheath tumors but differ histologically. They are not encapsulated and involve the nerve itself. They do not show the distinct Antoni A and B patterns or Verocay bodies seen in schwannomas.

 

Option C. Neuroma: Neuromas are non-neoplastic proliferations of nerve tissue, often occurring after nerve injury. They lack the distinctive histopathological features of spindle cells with palisading nuclei and Verocay bodies.

 

Option D. Glioma: Gliomas are primary tumors of the central nervous system originating from glial cells. They do not present with the histopathological features described and are not typically found in peripheral locations like the wrist joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schwannomas are characterized by spindle cells with palisading nuclei and Verocay bodies, forming well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses. These features, along with S-100 protein expression, distinguish schwannomas from other types of nerve sheath tumors and central nervous system tumors.

questions.text: A 1-day-old neonate has not passed urine since birth. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Continue breastfeeding and observe

 

  • A 1-day-old neonate not passing urine since birth is a normal finding in neonates. Continuing breastfeeding and observation is the next step in management.
  • Delay in passing urine or stool is a cause for concern and requires investigation.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Admit to NICU: This is not necessary as the absence of urination within the first 24 hours can be normal. Admission to NICU is reserved for cases where the neonate shows signs of distress or other serious conditions.

 

Option C. Start artificial feeding: This option is incorrect as breastfeeding should be continued unless there is a clear medical indication to switch to artificial feeding.

 

Option D. Start intravenous fluids: Starting IV fluids is not necessary unless the child shows signs of dehydration or is unable to take fluids orally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It is normal for a neonate to not pass urine within the first 24 hours; continue breastfeeding and observe the baby.

questions.text: A tumor arising from the uncinate process of the pancreas is most likely to compress which of the following vessels? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Superior mesenteric artery

 

A tumor of the uncinate process of pancreas affects the superior mesenteric artery.

 

Superior mesenteric artery originates from the anterior surface of the aorta just below the celiac trunk. It supplies blood to the midgut structures, including parts of the small intestine and the proximal large intestine.

 

Anatomically, the uncinate process of the pancreas lies posterior to the SMA, and its proximity means that tumors arising from the uncinate process can compress or invade the SMA.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Portal vein: It is formed posterior to the neck of the pancreas by the confluence of the superior mesenteric vein and the splenic vein. It conveys blood from the gastrointestinal tract and spleen to the liver. While tumors of the pancreas can involve the portal vein, especially those in the head and neck region, the uncinate process's direct relationship is more with the Superior mesenteric artery than with the portal vein.

 

Option C. Common hepatic artery: The common hepatic artery typically arises from the celiac trunk and bifurcates into the proper hepatic artery (supplying the liver) and the gastroduodenal artery. It runs superior to the head of the pancreas. While it's possible for a pancreatic tumor to involve this artery, especially if the tumor is extensive, the uncinate process's primary vascular relationship remains the Superior mesenteric artery.

 

Option D. Inferior mesenteric artery: It is the third major branch of the abdominal aorta and supplies blood to the hindgut structures, including the distal part of the large intestine. It is anatomically distant from the uncinate process of the pancreas, so it's less likely to be directly affected by a tumor in this location.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The uncinate process of the pancreas is a small extension of the pancreas that hooks around the superior mesenteric artery and vein. Its anatomical relations include:

 

Superiorly:

 

  • Neck of the pancreas

 

Inferiorly:

 

  • Superior mesenteric vein
  • Superior mesenteric artery

 

Anteriorly:

 

  • Third part of the duodenum
  • Root of the small bowel mesentery

 

Posteriorly:

 

  • Inferior vena cava
  • Aorta
  • Left renal vein
  • Left psoas muscle
  • Transverse mesocolon

 

Medially:

 

  • Pancreatic duct
  • Common bile duct

 

Laterally:

 

  • Right renal vessels
  • Right psoas muscle

 

The uncinate process is an important landmark for the surgeon during pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple procedure) as it is often involved in the dissection of the superior mesenteric vein and artery.Top of Form

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of asthma and sinusitis. On looking into his medical records, you notice this has been attributed to Samter's triad. Which drug should be avoided in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspirin

 

In a patient with Samter's triad, aspirin should be avoided as he will have aspirin intolerance.

 

Samter's triad is also known as aspirin-induced asthma or aspirin-sensitive asthma. It consists of:

 

  • Nasal polyposis
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Aspirin intolerance

 

Aspirin and COX – 1 inhibitors can exacerbate asthma hence they should be avoided. Rhinorrhea, conjunctival injection, facial flushing, and periorbital edema are also seen. Aspirin-induced hypersensitivity reactions also may occur.

 

The provocative challenge test with aspirin or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) is the only diagnostic method.

 

Aspirin desensitization is an important therapeutic option in patients with ST, especially in those patients suffering from recurrent NPs, anosmia, and overdependence on systemic corticosteroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cotrimoxazole and Option B. Co-amoxiclav: These are antibiotics used to treat bacterial infections, including sinusitis, and do not affect COX-1 activity.

 

Option D. Chloramphenicol: An antibiotic that is generally used for serious infections where other antibiotics are not suitable. It does not interact with the COX-1 pathway.

 

Educational Objective:


In patients diagnosed with Samter's triad, it is crucial to avoid aspirin and other NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1, as these can trigger severe respiratory and nasal symptoms. Effective management involves identifying safe medications for pain and inflammation and regularly monitoring the respiratory and nasal health of the patient.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 193, 194

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition exhibited by A. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Competitive inhibition

 

Competitive inhibition occurs when the inhibitor resembles the substrate and competes for binding to the active site of the enzyme. In the given graph, the presence of inhibitor A results in an increase in Km (Michaelis constant), indicating decreased enzyme affinity for the substrate due to competition. However, the Vmax (maximum velocity) remains unchanged, which is characteristic of competitive inhibition. The Lineweaver-Burk plot shows that the lines intersect on the y-axis, confirming that Vmax is unaffected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uncompetitive inhibition: This type of inhibition occurs when the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, leading to a decrease in both Km and Vmax. The lines in the Lineweaver-Burk plot are parallel, unlike the competitive inhibition plot seen here.

 

Option C. Mixed inhibition: In mixed inhibition, the inhibitor can bind to both the enzyme alone and the enzyme-substrate complex. This results in changes to both Km and Vmax, depending on the binding affinity. The graph shows altered Vmax with an intersection that is not on the y-axis, differing from competitive inhibition.

 

Option D. Non-competitive inhibition: Non-competitive inhibition occurs when the inhibitor binds to a site other than the active site, affecting the enzyme regardless of substrate binding. This results in decreased Vmax without altering Km, seen as lines intersecting on the x-axis in the Lineweaver-Burk plot, unlike the competitive inhibition pattern here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Competitive inhibition is identified by an increased Km and unchanged Vmax, with intersecting lines on the y-axis of the Lineweaver-Burk plot

questions.text: Identify the marked chamber? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left atrium

 

Explanation:

 

The radiological image shows a transverse section of the heart.

 

In a CT scan taken with the patient lying supine, the right atrium and right ventricle will be seen on the front side, while the left atrium and left ventricle will be at the back. The base (posterior surface) of the heart is mainly formed by the left atrium (two-thirds) and the right atrium (one-third).

 

In the image, the vertebra is at the back, and the aorta is on the left side in front of the vertebra. The esophagus is closely related to the base of the heart, particularly the left atrium. The chamber marked in the question is the one just in front of the esophagus is the left atrium.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right atrium: The right atrium is towards the right side and forms the right border of the heart in this view.

 

Option C. Right ventricle: The right ventricle lies on the front side along with the right atrium. It forms the sternocostal surface of the heart. The marked chamber is at the back, so it cannot be the right ventricle.

 

Option D. Left ventricle: The left ventricle lies next to the left atrium at the back in this transverse section. However, the marked chamber is the one closest to the esophagus, which is the left atrium, not the left ventricle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a transverse CT section of the heart, the right atrium and ventricle are seen anteriorly, while the left atrium and ventricle are seen posteriorly.

questions.text: Identify the vitamin deficiency: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin D

 

Vitamin D The image show Bowing of the legs, a condition known as bowlegs or genu varum, is commonly associated with Vitamin D deficiency, especially in children. Vitamin D plays a crucial role in the regulation of calcium and phosphorus, essential minerals for bone health. Deficiency of Vitamin D can lead to improper mineralization of bones, resulting in deformities such as bowing of the legs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency is not typically associated with bowing of the legs. However, severe vitamin A deficiency cause night blindness and other eye menifestations.

 

Option C. Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Vitamin B3 deficiency can cause pellagra, which involves skin, gastrointestinal, and neurological symptoms. It is not directly linked to bowing of the legs.

 

Option D. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Vitamin B1 deficiency can lead to beriberi, a condition that primarily affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems. It is not a common cause of bowing of the legs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin D

questions.text: A young man came to the medical OPD with complaints of early morning backache and stiffness, which improves on exercise, and persistent red eyes. On examination, lung expansion was less than 3 cm. X-ray is shown in the image given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints, leading to pain and stiffness. The hallmark feature of AS is inflammatory back pain, which is characterized by pain and stiffness that are worse in the morning and improve with exercise. The persistent red eyes are indicative of anterior uveitis, a common extra-articular manifestation of AS.

 

The reduced lung expansion (less than 3 cm) points towards involvement of the thoracic spine, leading to restrictive lung disease due to reduced chest wall mobility. The X-ray image shows characteristic changes of AS, including syndesmophytes and the "bamboo spine" appearance, which result from the ossification of ligaments and entheses (where tendons and ligaments attach to the bone).

 

Bamboo spine

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paget's disease: This condition is characterized by abnormal bone remodeling but does not typically present with inflammatory back pain or extra-articular manifestations such as uveitis.

 

Option C. Healed tuberculosis: While tuberculosis can affect the spine (Pott's disease), it does not present with the classic inflammatory back pain or the characteristic radiographic changes seen in AS.

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis: This is a rare genetic disorder that leads to increased bone density and brittleness but does not present with the clinical and radiographic features of AS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ankylosing spondylitis should be suspected in young patients with inflammatory back pain that improves with exercise, reduced lung expansion, and extra-articular manifestations such as uveitis. The "bamboo spine" on X-ray is a characteristic finding in advanced cases of AS.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing implant surgery for his upper limb. On giving general anesthesia he develops tachycardia, sudden raise in body temperature and rigidity of muscles. What drug is most likely to have caused this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Halothane

 

The symptoms described in the scenario—tachycardia, hyperthermia, and muscle rigidity—are classic signs of malignant hyperthermia, a life-threatening condition that can be triggered by certain anesthetic agents, most notably volatile anesthetics like halothane and depolarizing muscle relaxants such as succinylcholine. Halothane is one of the most well-known triggers of malignant hyperthermia, especially in genetically susceptible individuals. The condition is due to an abnormal release of calcium in muscle cells, leading to intense muscle contractions, increased metabolism, and excessive heat production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propofol: Propofol is a widely used intravenous anesthetic agent that does not trigger malignant hyperthermia. Instead, it is often used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia due to its favorable safety profile.

 

Option C. Etomidate: Etomidate is another intravenous anesthetic commonly used for induction, particularly in patients with cardiovascular instability. Like propofol, it does not trigger malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option D. Nitrous oxide: Nitrous oxide is a carrier gas that provides analgesia and sedation but is not associated with triggering malignant hyperthermia. It is often used in combination with other anesthetics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Halothane, a volatile anesthetic, is a known trigger for malignant hyperthermia, characterized by hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, and tachycardia, especially in genetically predisposed individuals.

questions.text: At the Urban Primary Health Centre (U-PHC), you are in charge of managing hypertension clinic services. You have 50 patients transferred from another healthcare unit for hypertension management; 40 of these patients are prescribed amlodipine (5mg, daily) and 10 are on lisinopril (10mg, daily) due to contraindications with amlodipine. Considering the need for continuous treatment and potential increases in patient numbers, calculate the number of tablets needed for the next month and determine the appropriate reorder factor. [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 3000, rf=2

 

Calculation -  

 

Requirement of Amlodipine

 

40 patients x 1 Tablet per day x 30 Days = 1200 Tablets

 

Requirement of Lisinopril

 

10 patients x 1 Tablet per day x 30 Days = 300 Tablets

 

Reorder factor (Rf) for drugs supplied every:

 

  • 1 Month - 2
  • 3 Months - 6
  • 6 Months – 12

 

For the given question,

 

Total of 1500 tablets are required and reorder factor is 2

 

Hence, Total tablets required = (1200 + 300) x 2 = 3000 Tablets

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Reorder Factor (rf): A reorder factor of 2 is commonly used for monthly resupply scenarios to account for unexpected increases in patient count or dosage adjustments, ensuring no interruption in patient care.

questions.text: Phototherapy converts bilirubin to? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lumirubin

 

Phototherapy is a standard treatment for neonatal jaundice and indirect hyperbilirubinemia. The primary purpose of phototherapy is to reduce elevated bilirubin levels in the blood by converting the toxic unconjugated bilirubin into a form that can be more easily excreted by the body.

 

Mechanisms involved in phototherapy:

 

  1. Irreversible Structural Isomerization: This is the most important mechanism of phototherapy. It converts bilirubin into lumirubin, a more water-soluble isomer that can be excreted by the kidneys in an unconjugated form. Lumirubin is more easily excreted in the urine, reducing serum bilirubin levels.
  2. Reversible Photo-isomerization Reaction: This process converts toxic unconjugated bilirubin into a non-toxic configurational isomer, which can be excreted in the bile without conjugation.
  3. Photo-oxidation: This is a minor mechanism where bilirubin undergoes oxidation to form colorless products that are also excreted.

 

Contraindications: Phototherapy is contraindicated in conditions like porphyria, where exposure to light can cause severe photosensitivity and blistering.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stercobilin: This is a bile pigment formed from the breakdown of bilirubin in the intestines, giving stool its characteristic brown color. It is not directly involved in the process of phototherapy.

 

Option C. Biliverdin: Biliverdin is a precursor to bilirubin in the heme breakdown pathway. Phototherapy does not convert bilirubin back to biliverdin.

 

Option D. Urobilin: Urobilin is a product of bilirubin metabolism that is excreted in the urine, giving urine its yellow color. It is not the primary product of phototherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phototherapy converts bilirubin into lumirubin, a water-soluble isomer that can be excreted by the kidneys, making it an effective treatment for neonatal jaundice.

questions.text:
Calculate the ECF volume in a volunteer in whom 10 gm of mannitol was injected in venous blood. At equilibrium urinary excretion of mannitol was found to be 10% and the plasma concentration of mannitol was 65 mg/100 ml?

In a volunteer, 10 grams of mannitol was injected into the venous blood. At equilibrium, the urinary excretion of mannitol was found to be 10% and the plasma concentration of mannitol was measured at 65 mg/100 ml. Calculate the extracellular fluid (ECF) volume based on this information. (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 14L

 

ECF volume of the above volunteer is calculated to be 14 L.

 

Mannitol is a marker of ECF volume as it does not cross the cell membrane and remains in the ECF.

 

The ECF volume can be calculated using the formula:

 

 

Where,

 

  • V = ECF volume
  • Amount injected = 10 gm
  • Amount of mannitol excreted = 10% of 10 gm = 1gm

  • Plasma concentration of mannitol = 65 mg/100mL = 0.65 gm/L

     

Calculation:

 

ECF Volume = (10-1) /0.65 = 13.8 L = approximately 14 L

 

Educational Objective:

 

The extracellular fluid (ECF) volume can be calculated by using the dilution principle, taking into account the amount of marker substance injected, the amount excreted, and the plasma concentration of the marker.
